gloss.p: A criminal act defined as "a serious, violent attack on someone" with a deadly weapon. (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The processing of individuals who have committed criminal acts." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Having officially been found guilty of a crime in a law court." (Cambridge Dictionary)

"If someone who has committed a crime is pardoned, that person is officially forgiven and their punishment is stopped." (Cambridge Dictionary)"An act of mercy by a person in authority toward someone who has committed a crime, esp. by reducing a punishment." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The hearing of statements and showing of objects, etc. in a law court to judge if a person is guilty of a crime or to decide a case or a legal matter." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Someone whose job is to give advice to people about the law and speak for them in court." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A place where trials and other legal cases happen, or the people present in such a place." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A group of people who have been chosen to listen to the facts in a court action and decide whether a person is guilty or not guilty or whether a claim has been proved." (Cambridge Dictionary)

Divorced or separated individuals are individuals who have undergone "an official or legal process of ending a marriage" (Cambridge Dictionary). While official divorce requires legal processes, those of separated status often functionally dissolve their marriage and live independently without obtaining a legal divorce, often due to the high cost and difficulty of undergoing the legal process. In the nineteenth century, many separations were also the result of desertion, or one party leaving the other with no notice or legal separation.

The number of divorced or separated individuals increased greatly in the nineteenth-century United States. Individual state governments, rather than the federal government, regulated their own divorce laws, and many states broadened their laws to offer more grounds for divorce, including adultery, impotence, abuse, and abandonment. While marriages were granted more frequently and for more reasons, women seeking divorces from their husbands remained at a severe disadvantage. Coverture, the legal process wherein women ceased to have a legal identity apart from their husbands, often rendered nineteenth-century American women economically dependent upon their husbands, while social norms led divorced women to be stigmatized or shunned socially by their peers. Divorce also remained a contentious issue within American society, as some, particularly among religious leaders, sought to further limit access to divorce, while many reformers, especially among women's rights advocates, sought to further increase access to divorce.

Statistics concerning divorce varied along economic, racial, and regional lines, yet ultimately the United States saw a sharp rise in divorce and separation throughout the nineteenth century and beyond" (Encyclopedia of the United States in the Nineteenth Century, Vol. 1, 380-2; Wikipedia).

catDesc.term: African Americans--Historically Free and Newly Freed

Categories:

gloss.p: Historically free African Americans included people who were both African American and lived as and/or were legally free before the American Civil War. They may or may not have previously been enslaved. In recognition of African American military service during the Revolutionary War, a number of states moved to gradually abolish slavery leading to a growing body of free African Americans.

Freedom, however, did not mean citizenship, and despite efforts by free Black activists to settle this question and affirm their citizenship, it was largely left to state lawmakers who otherwise failed to settle the question. Consequently, during the Antebellum era, each southern state passed different laws governing the place and rights of free African Americans. Home to the nation's largest free African American community, for example, Baltimore, Maryland registered 25,000 free Black residents by 1850. (Martha S. Jones, Birthright Citizens: A History of Race and Rights in Antebellum America, p. 13)

In another example, South Carolina's Act of 1820 distinguished between those freed before and after 1820, and classified free African Americans as "denizens," which limited citizenship rights by a series of Black Codes. In response to rebellions, numerous states passed legal restrictions that made manumission virtually impossible by the mid-nineteenth century. Loved ones who purchased family members were forced to legally hold them in bondage, leading to a body of people who "were free by practice, but not by law." (Amrita Chakrabarti Myers, Forging Freedom, 3–4, 207)

Unlike South Carolina, Mississippi's judiciary ruled that “free negroes . . . are to be regarded as alien enemies or strangers prohibited, and without the pale of comity, and incapable of acquiring or maintaining property in this State which will be recognized by our courts.” (Heirn v. Bridault, 37 Miss. 209, 224–25, 1859 in Jones, Birthright Citizens, p. 213) The state's strict provisions on manumission led to an extremely small population of free African Americans (773 people by 1860) during the antebellum era ("Free Blacks in Antebellum Mississippi," Mississippi Encyclopedia)

Newly freed African Americans includes people who were enslaved but became free by the passage of the Emancipation Proclamation and/or the Thirteenth Amendment. While neither was comprehensive, the Emancipation Proclamation of 1863 freed the enslaved in territories under rebellion, and later the Thirteenth Amendment of 1865 abolished slavery altogether, except when used as a punishment for those who committed a crime and did not apply to Native Nations who practices slavery. (American Battlefield Trust; Wikipedia) In the CWRGM collection, African Americans after December 6, 1865 are classified as historically free or newly freed.

gloss.p: The Cambridge Dictionary classifies "a person who lives in the U.S. and is a member of a race of people with dark skin that originally came from Africa" as African American, but both the nineteenth-century and modern constructions are more complex (Cambridge Dictionary). Common nineteenth-century racial categories such as "mulatto" referred to persons with both white and black ancestry, and the experiences of mixed-race persons varied based on complexion, degree of African ancestry, and the region in which they lived. In antebellum cities with large populations of free Blacks, the degree of one's African ancestry could determine what rights one possessed or did not possess, and people with lighter skin tones were often considered to be white; this ended under "one drop rule" during the Jim Crow system.

Like skin tone, the ethnicity implied by the term "African American" is also problematically broad, as "naming people only by the continent of their origin and ignoring their ethnic identity is a consequence of time and space" (Painter, Creating Black Americans, 5). The experience of slavery complicated the term by attempting to strip people of their original distinct African ethnic identities such as Ibo or Ndongan, classifying all persons of African descent together under one term, infusing that term with negative connotation, and disregarding the complex and rich linguistic, cultural, and ethnic histories of varied African people. However, many Black Americans have reclaimed the term "African American" and infused it with positive connotations. One scholar argues that "in using the term 'African Americans,' Black Americans accent the part of their heritage that is not American" (Painter, Creating Black Americans, 4).

CWRGM — acknowledging the multiplicity of the term's meanings and connotations — includes multiracial and multiethnic people of African descent under the "African Americans" social identifiers subject tag to reflect the diversity of the African American experience and to ensure that the experiences of African Americans of mixed races and ethnicities are discoverable as they are rarely distinguished further in the letters. In the absence of other references, CWRGM also tags racial slurs targeted at African Americans — which were common in nineteenth century documents with white authors — under the "African Americans" tag. CWRGM recognizes the historic and present harm caused by such language and does not condone its use but tags these terms only to ensure the rich history of African Americans are discoverable within the collection.

element.value: From the Mississippi Department of Archives and History Governor Alcorn Collection. Letter from H. S. Van Eaton at Woodville, Mississippi, to R. J. Mathews, recounting the case of Elisha Boker and stating that he ought to have never been convicted, stating that the prosecutor had gone to the cabin of Boker looking for a woman that was staying there. When Elisha came out, the prosecutor tried to attack Elisha with a long piece of iron. Van Eaton claims Elisha defended himself with a knife, cutting the prosecutor. Van Eaton also accuses the witnesses in the case, all African Americans, of being prejudiced against Boker. Van Eaton requests executive clemency for Boker.

div.p:
[stamp] H. S. VAN EATON,
Attorney at Law,
WOODVILLE, MISS. [/stamp]
I am glad to have an opportunity to make a statement in reference to Elisha Baker—This poor fellow ought never to have been convicted—

The testimony substantially was—that on the Evening of the alleged "assault with intent to kill" Elisha had retired to his Cabin—it was just after Dark—In the Cabin lived with Elisha a woman formerly the wife of the prosecutor—the party assaulted—also some children—some of the Children were crying. The prosecutor came to the Cabin & Demanded to know "What was the matter with those children", & called to Elisha to come out—(It should here be stated that the woman had long since been abandoned by the prosecutor—that he had no claim on her, or rights in the Cabin where she & the children & Elisha were staying)—The Door was shut, Elisha opened it & stepped out. Soon there were angry words—finally the prosecutor advanced on Elisha with a piece of round iron about 2 or 3 feet long & an inch in diameter—at this juncture
Elisha picked up a knife, and as the prosecutor struck or attempted to strike him with the bar of iron he (Elisha) cut the prosecutor with the knife, which ended the encounter—

It was evident on the trial, the witnesses all negroes, were prejudiced against Baker—nevertheless the Jury found him Guilty as Charged, & the court regarding the matter as so peculiarly within the province of the Jury refused a new trial—It is proper also to state that the above account of the affair was given by the State's Witnesses—I took great interest in the case & when I mention that I was acting without fee or hope of reward, you will see I was disinterested—I afterwards got up a petition for pardon but it never succeeded—
I know it was the opinion of the bar here that Elisha ought not to have been convicted—

I ought perhaps also to mention that the knife was one ordinarily in use about the cabin, a sort of butcher knife I think, & that it happened to be laying near at the time of the assault on Elisha by the prosecutor—
In conclusion I can only say in all my practice I have never known
a case more justly deserving Executive clemency & I sincerely hope it may be Extended—
I presume I have stated what the committee wish to know viz my Knowledge & remembrance of the facts as testified to on the trial &c—
